channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: How do 'torpedo bats' work? We asked baseball physicists to explain
item.description: They look like baseball bats morphing into bowling pins, their ends flaring into an aggressive bulge that suddenly tapers. So how do they work?
item.content:encoded:
They look like baseball bats morphing into bowling pins, their ends flaring into an aggressive bulge that suddenly tapers. So how do they work?

(Image credit: Mike Stobe)
item.dc:creator: Bill Chappell

item.title: How reciprocal tariffs could affect you. And, Maryland man mistakenly deported
item.description: Trump is expected to impose "reciprocal tariffs," which economists believe could be painful for U.S. consumers. And, the Trump administration says it mistakenly deported a man to El Salvador.
item.content:encoded:
Trump is expected to impose "reciprocal tariffs," which economists believe could be painful for U.S. consumers. And, the Trump administration says it mistakenly deported a man to El Salvador.

(Image credit: Chris Kleponis/CNP)
item.dc:creator: Brittney Melton

item.title: Latest Alzheimer's lab tests focus on memory loss, not brain plaques
item.description: New tests of blood and spinal fluid can identify people experiencing memory loss from Alzheimer's disease.
item.content:encoded:
New tests of blood and spinal fluid can identify people experiencing memory loss from Alzheimer's disease.

(Image credit: Andrew Brookes)
item.dc:creator: Jon Hamilton

item.title: Today is Trump's 'Liberation Day.' What does that mean for tariffs?
item.description: President Trump has been promising new "reciprocal tariffs" to punish other countries for their tariffs and trade barriers. Markets are nervous that a trade war could hike prices and hurt the economy.
item.content:encoded:
President Trump has been promising new "reciprocal tariffs" to punish other countries for their tariffs and trade barriers. Markets are nervous that a trade war could hike prices and hurt the economy.

(Image credit: Saul Loeb)
item.dc:creator: Danielle Kurtzleben

item.title: States say Trump's continued freeze on much-needed FEMA aid violates a judge's order
item.description: Twenty-two states say the Trump administration is illegally freezing money from the Federal Emergency Management Agency. The administration says the funding is just being "reviewed" and isn't frozen.
item.content:encoded:
Twenty-two states say the Trump administration is illegally freezing money from the Federal Emergency Management Agency. The administration says the funding is just being "reviewed" and isn't frozen.

(Image credit: Zayrha Rodriguez)
item.dc:creator: Chris Arnold

item.title: Here's what to do if you're caught driving in high winds, tornadoes or dust storms
item.description: "Wind is unlike many other hazards because you really can't see it," says AAA's Bill Van Tassel.
item.content:encoded:
"Wind is unlike many other hazards because you really can't see it," says AAA's Bill Van Tassel.

(Image credit: Josh Edelson)
item.dc:creator: Joe Hernandez

item.title: The U.S. already has tariffs on a few sectors. It hasn't gone that great
item.description: The U.S. has generally kept tariffs low, but a few domestic industries have long been protected by import taxes and other trade barriers. They offer clues about how Trump's new tariffs might work out.
item.content:encoded:
The U.S. has generally kept tariffs low, but a few domestic industries have long been protected by import taxes and other trade barriers. They offer clues about how Trump's new tariffs might work out.

(Image credit: Jeff Kowalsky)
item.dc:creator: Scott Horsley

item.title: Supreme Court to decide if states can strip Planned Parenthood of Medicaid funds
item.description: At issue is whether a state, in this case, South Carolina, can remove Planned Parenthood clinics from its state Medicaid program, even though Medicaid funds cannot generally be used to fund abortions.
item.content:encoded:
At issue is whether a state, in this case, South Carolina, can remove Planned Parenthood clinics from its state Medicaid program, even though Medicaid funds cannot generally be used to fund abortions.

(Image credit: Andrew Harnik)
item.dc:creator: Nina Totenberg

item.title: It's been a wild rollout of Trump's tariffs. Here's how we got here
item.description: President Trump's tariff talk has been big — and also unpredictable. He's frequently made threats only to back off or shift deadlines. Here, a look at how the tariff agenda has rolled out.
item.content:encoded:
President Trump's tariff talk has been big — and also unpredictable. He's frequently made threats only to back off or shift deadlines. Here, a look at how the tariff agenda has rolled out.

(Image credit: Geoff Robins)
item.dc:creator: Heidi Glenn

item.title: Judge orders White House to restore legal aid to unaccompanied migrant children
item.description: A federal judge in California has ordered the Trump administration to temporarily restore legal aid to tens of thousands of migrant children who are in the United States without a parent or guardian.
item.content:encoded:
A federal judge in California has ordered the Trump administration to temporarily restore legal aid to tens of thousands of migrant children who are in the United States without a parent or guardian.

(Image credit: Eric Gay)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
